title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with most individuals facing capital charges unable to afford their own attorney and no state meeting ABA standards for indigent prisoners' legal representation. Since 1976, African-Americans have accounted for a disproportionate number of executions and individuals on death row, despite only making up 13% of the population. White victims make up the majority of death penalty cases, even though they are only 50% of murder victims. In the Federal system, 67 percent of those on death row are waiting for execution. Despite only 50 percent of murder victims being white, 84 percent of victims in death penalty cases are white. A study found that 89 percent of defendants chosen for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. The General Accounting Office reported racial disparities in capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988, with a majority of defendants being African-American or Hispanic American. The Supreme Court's rulings since 1976 have limited the rights of death row prisoners, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent individuals. Prisoner appeals have been restricted since 1976, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent people. In 1996, new legislation further limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners. The Federal and State death penalty is on hold until Congress reviews the National Commission on the Death Penalty's findings and recommendations. The Commission's guidelines and procedures must be either implemented or rejected through legislation repealing this section. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President in consultation with relevant officials. Members include Federal or State prosecutors and experienced attorneys. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members, including Federal or State prosecutors, attorneys experienced in capital defense, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty comprises 15 members, including state law enforcement officials and individuals with expertise in various relevant fields from the public or private sector. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members from diverse backgrounds, including academia, nonprofit organizations, the religious community, industry, and other interested individuals. The President appoints members with balanced viewpoints on the use of the death penalty. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members with diverse backgrounds, appointed by the President. The members have balanced opinions on the use of the death penalty. The initial appointments should be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and any vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, consisting of 15 members appointed by the President, must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed. The Commission will meet at the call of the Chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for conducting business. The President will designate one member to serve as the Chair, and the Commission will adopt rules and procedures to govern its proceedings. SEC. 202. Duties of the Commission. The Commission is required to conduct a comprehensive study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles and fairness. This study will include examining racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions. The study on the administration of the death penalty will examine racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions, including adequacy of representation for capital defendants. The study will also consider the adequacy of representation for capital defendants, including adherence to ABA guidelines and policies to ensure competent counsel. It will also investigate cases of wrongful convictions leading to death sentences and discuss whether the Federal government should pursue the death penalty. The study will investigate wrongful convictions in death penalty cases, the Federal government's role in seeking the death penalty in states without it, and the evaluation of courts' independent judgment on constitutional claims in post-conviction proceedings. The study will explore issues such as the sentencing of mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death, access to forensic evidence for death row inmates, and other laws and procedures to ensure justice in death penalty cases. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for administering the death penalty, ensuring fairness and impartiality in accordance with the Constitution. This includes access to forensic evidence and DNA testing to potentially uncover new evidence of innocence. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for administering the death penalty to ensure fairness, impartiality, and minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for administering the death penalty to ensure fairness, impartiality, and minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals. Additionally, they will ensure that the death penalty is not administered in a racially discriminatory manner. The Commission is required to submit a preliminary report within one year and a final report within two years of the enactment of this Act. The Commission will submit a preliminary report with initial findings and a final report with detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President, Attorney General, and Congress within two years of the Act's enactment. The Commission is granted powers under Section 203. The Commission may obtain necessary information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as granted under Section 203. The Commission can accept gifts, conduct hearings, and subpoena witnesses for necessary information. The Commission has the authority to subpoena witnesses and documents for necessary information, with subpoenas issued by the Chairperson and served by designated individuals. The Commission can issue subpoenas signed by the Chairperson and served by designated individuals. Failure to comply may result in a court order to testify or provide evidence. A court in the United States can issue an order for a subpoenaed person to testify or produce evidence, failure to comply may result in contempt. Additionally, a court can issue a writ of habeas for testimony of a person in custody sought by the Commission. States may issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person in custody before the Commission upon application by the Attorney General. Witness allowances and fees follow the provisions of title 28, United States Code. Witness allowances and fees for witnesses requested or subpoenaed to appear at Commission hearings will be paid per diem and mileage allowances from Commission funds, following the provisions of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation. They are allowed travel expenses and the Chairperson can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson can also determine their compensation independently. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and staff, and set their compensation without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can also be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff with compensation not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It may spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
